instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H_CPU: What is PPBUS_G3H_CPU? PPBUS_G3H_CPU is the .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .

threads.title: Macbook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted
threads.message:
Hi, 
I got for repair MacBook Pro 13" 820- 00875-A after liquid damage. 
I check all rails and  <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is shorted 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 13.10V 
SN650839 have some voltages coming out:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_LDO5V</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_LDO3V</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_PMIC</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP1V25_VREF</SIGNAL>
all those are present 
voltage on <CAPACITOR>C7960</CAPACITOR> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU</SIGNAL> 13.10V 
SMC have communication with charger as its changing from 5V to 20V after plug it in. 
I do some checks but not really able to find what causing short, after insert 3V into this rail nothing really gets hot on board only CPU a bit. Mainboard takes 4,5A on this rail at the moment. 
I have removed <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> and <CHIP>U8205</CHIP> and  to check if this will cause short but it is not. 
Any more ideas ?
Thanks

threads.title: Macbook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted
threads.message:
Start injecting with 1V and go up; no more than 3.7V and less than Amp limit of your becnh power supply.
BTW, the exact value of the short?
Of course, remove heatsink and tocuh CPU die directly with the finger.

threads.title: Macbook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted
threads.message: Hi, i tested board with removed heatsink previously and now again and one side of cpu gets hot, exact value 1.1Ohm on the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> rail. Also I have second working board to compare resistance and on L8060 its only 1.2ohm same on L7900. On working board resistance is around 56ohm on this two coils.

threads.title: Macbook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted
threads.message:
"resistance and on L8060 its only 1.2ohm same on L7900"
Both go to PCH; clearly marked on L7900 side.
So you have short not only on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>; which also goes to PCH.
When you find short on 2-3 power supply, the common load is first suspect PCH in this case.

"one side of cpu gets hot"
I bet for PCH area...

threads.title: Macbook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted
threads.message: Medium size core and this area gets hot, is it PCH? I bet it is...

threads.title: Macbook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted
threads.message:
If is two dies package, smaller one is PCH.

For one big die only, CPU area is close to VCORE coils.
PCH is on the other side of die; you can see RTC components placed near it.

threads.title: Macbook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted
threads.message: With all measurements and checking looks like CPU/PCH is gone... Have you ever try to replace it ? I have replace many GPU PCH and older CPU successfully but never try to replace any of this newest Intel. They are expensive so I wondering is it even worth to trying. Thanks

threads.title: Macbook Pro 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted
threads.message: I never changed one and I don't think to do it ever...
